summary: This document is an email chain from December 2020 discussing concerns that the US Virgin Islands Attorney General's office is interfering with the federal criminal investigation into Jeffrey Epstein by issuing subpoenas and contacting witnesses. The emails strategize about how to get the USVI AG to stand down or coordinate, including potentially seeking a stay or having DOJ supervisors intervene.

persons.name: Linda Singer
persons.role: Private attorney representing the US Virgin Islands
persons.context: Attorney from the firm Motley Rice who represents the USVI in its civil suit against Epstein's estate and who reached out to the federal prosecutors to ask for information from their investigation.

persons.name: Judge Freeman
persons.context: Granted a motion for a stay in a related civil lawsuit, which is noted as a positive development for the federal prosecutors.

connections.description: Linda Singer, a private attorney with Motley Rice, is representing the US Virgin Islands Attorney General's office in its civil suit against Epstein's estate.

events.title: Initial Contact with USVI Counsel
events.description: Federal prosecutors spoke with counsel to the USVI (Linda Singer) and raised concerns about their civil suit interfering with the criminal case. The attorney said she would consult with the USVI AG and get back, but never did.

events.title: Discovery of USVI Subpoenas
events.description: Federal prosecutors learned that the USVI AG had been issuing a number of subpoenas to individuals, indicating they were not willing to cooperate at the 'line level'.

events.title: Motion for Stay Granted
events.description: Judge Freeman granted a motion for a stay in a related civil lawsuit, which the prosecutors viewed as helpful for their position.

keyFacts: The US Virgin Islands Attorney General's office filed a civil suit against Epstein's estate and was actively investigating, issuing subpoenas and contacting witnesses.

Federal prosecutors from the Southern District of New York were concerned the USVI's actions would interfere with their criminal case, potentially contaminating witnesses and causing trial exhibits (like flight records) to be leaked.
The USVI was represented by private attorney Linda Singer from the firm Motley Rice, who had previously contacted federal prosecutors to ask for information from their investigation.
Prosecutors strategized about escalating contact to supervisors at the USVI AG's office to demand they stand down or at least coordinate witness contacts.
A judge (Freeman) had already granted a stay in a related civil matter, which prosecutors saw as leverage to potentially seek a stay against the USVI's actions.
